items.title: 7 Minutes with Bebeto: Dear January
items.author: Bebeto Nyamwamu
items.description:
Dear January,

What did you decide this time around?

We expected you to be blue. And you disappointed us. I’ve not heard people cry for spending too much in your brother December and having little in your time.

Not that we really wanted you to be blue. We’re used to patterns and the obvious. You became Mourinho. And mind games became your forte.

You’ve come to pass swiftly. Very unusual of you. We’ve known you to have extra days in your bag. Like in the past year I counted 44 days in your name. This time you seemed like 28 only.

Now, there’s only one distress when you pass on quickly: paying of monthly bills. That’s something all of us (who stay in rented apartments) don’t like. We dread moments of landlord visitations. Not to check on us but to seek what’s due to them.

The fear will fade when you let your followers get my paycheck.

On we go….

What made you run out fast? Now we’re in February. A different February with an extra day. Will the extra day make a difference in the 366? That’s what am looking forward to when we get to the end of the tether. Please pass my message to February for her to be compassionate to me. Let me earn in her time.

But for now, what did I do in your time?

In your time I learnt to appreciate and love family for the times I have them. God forbid! They can pass on but you’ve to push on.

In your time I learnt that you need to commit to small routines to form habits. So, if you want to stop or start something, do it in small bits and it will grow to be an asset.

In your time I learnt through a CD of being adaptable to that my ambitions can fit in this small world. Where mountains don’t meet but people.

In your time I enjoyed the comfort you offered. You made sure it rained. So, I could not smell the dust. Your past namesakes are usually very warm. But you changed this year to be cool enough for me to be homely. Should I thank you? Or you were not really in control. Still, am thinking you had something to do with the weather.

In your time, you shoved me into looking at things with a second eye. Is it enough to get only the first premise? Why not get as many premises? Having options makes you powerful. Powerful to make doors where there were none.

Now those are the highlights of what happened in your time. Am happy and grateful for your time.

When you hand over the baton to Feb tell her to be resplendent (been fighting my fairies to use it)

I await with pleasure to see your memo reach Feb. I’ll evaluate if you really are a good listener and follow through with what I tell you.

…

This year am trying to keep a monthly journal where I creatively speak to my months what they have offered me. And what I would like for the months that are yet to pass. So, lean forward and glean my learning positions.

You’ll see a journal reflecting upon what has already happened. And to hope and work with aspirations for the upcoming month.

While I was writing this edition, I couldn’t help but think of how creative instincts were bred in us in our childhood.

If you ever managed an English class from standard one then you remember composition. It was a tedious test. To fill in the required words. To organise your thoughts and write meaningful sentences. And the scramble for the 40 points. You and I managed the period well.

At a point in class 4 when I was starting the challenge, I would have one pattern of starting my sentences. The compositions would be pegged on proverbs, a start line, an ending line or a subject. I never liked the writing. But then I had to cope.

I could only try to string in a few words. From there my mind would blackout. My diction was only starting to grow. Therefore, my teachers would impel me, with a dose of the cane, to read a lot of stories. From magazines to storybooks.

One thing stands out here. I learnt the lingo. Even though through toil. Since imitation is the best form of learning, I picked phrases that rhymed with my soul then would use them like my own. From my reads.

Like in my childhood or yours, imitation forms a major part of our learning even into adulthood. We pick and run with what we see is good for us. While on it make sure it works for you.

As of now enjoy thinking what your childhood made you become.

ciao!

items.title: 700 Words with Bebeto: All izz well
items.author: Bebeto Nyamwamu
items.description:
Dear Bebeto,

I don’t want to ask you how you are doing? Still, I am forced to go on and ask.

I hope this letter finds you well. When we last met you told me you’re looking for a job. Have you found one?

I am in dire need of pocket money. And the only person I can think of to help me is you. You’re the only one 😉 who can spoil me. Spoil me with things I see in movies. With a blend of your own style.

I am anticipating how this year will be good. So, don’t panic for any bumps you meet.

It’s all gonna be well. Rise to any challenge and refer to the line ‘All izz well’.

You again told me that you don’t do upcountry. How unfortunate! Yet when you come around, you pick foodstuff like there’s no food in your beloved Nairobae.

Have you ever stopped to think of how a food basket upcountry is? If its matoke, saga, managu, fresh Sukuma, and mahindi choma. Name it all. You’ll find it here.

How’s Nairobbery? I hope you have not misplaced your phone. I have been told countless stories about how ngetas have made goodies get new owners. You know how our Kenya is(our economy is that bad). Young kids are fending for themselves. And the easiest option is grabbing.

Not grabbing land and taxes 😣😣😒 like our politicians are doing.

Brother, I am hoping you make it. One day I want to visit you in those posh neighbourhoods. Where I will smell the wealthy air (as if the wealthy have their own). I want someday to blow my trumpet for greeting the Wanjigis at the estate shops. I wish someday to import toilet paper from abroad.

I look up to you urbanite. There’s a lot I learn from you when you’re around. Remember showing me how to operate a smartphone? Thanks to you I can now WhatsApp. I also know what bundles are and am running the village Sacco WhatsApp group.

As I write this, I recall how you ended 2019 and started 2020 in grief. I don’t want to remind you. Because my words will easily prick your tear glands. So, be strong and enjoy the time you have with family and friends.

Now going back. You’ll get a job. Things happen and your job is on its way from heaven(you’re a believer, right?). And good things don’t come easy.

On my end, I am also trying to inveigle life. Planting Sukuma, beans, onions, and cassava. I have also started doing fowls. So that when you visit, you can have feeds to carry.

A whole lot of managing soil to see foods grow is all a lot challenging. In the past season, there were sporadic rains. So, my plants didn’t grow to a bumper harvest. And it’s the reason for your recent visit you manage to carry less than your usual.

Meanwhile, as we dread the locust to get here have the requisite quietude in your endeavours. For ‘All humanity’s problems stem from man’s inability to sit quietly in a room’. Some solutions come in stillness and patience.

Until we meet wait for the next write. It might take a while as I am taking care of things around here. Taking care of grandma and grandpa. Not forgetting the chores that come with having a shamba. Like the cows, goats, fowls. And my newly found project of doing onions, beans, cassava. It will take a toll on me doing all those and penning down to tell you how we’re faring.

But for the little moments, I’ll get, be sure I will poke you.

P.S. Put a fight every day.
P.P.S Not the literal fight of picking fights with friends and people around you. But with daring situations.

items.title: 7 Minutes with Bebeto: Did I live up to my promise?
items.author: Bebeto Nyamwamu
items.description:
There are times plans A and B don’t work out — they don’t serve you. They end up serving themselves. You plan in the head, you’ll manage with either if one fails. Then it comes to pass both were really

The other day I had two meetings, one hour apart in a city where traffic is a nightmare! One with a Creative D whose agency I wished to join the team, the other… let’s just say am a job hunter. So, had to kill two meetings with me and traffic.

Had promised myself to be early. To be early meant making an impression 😉 on the CD. And finishing up quite early to have enough moments to carry my body to the next meeting.

Did I live up to my promise? Your guess is as good as mine. Didn’t make it early enough. And instead, I was racing against time. And finally had to let him know I was running late. A very big disappointment. To my ambition. And by the wait, the CD had to go through.

And I was in town.

In between the fluster tailing me, I had to make a brief meetup on short notice. According to the person on the phone earlier, the situation was parlous. He met me and I relieved him. About what we discussed…it’s a story for another day.

Note my cruise to meeting the CD had taken a break as if to catch a breath. It also involved boarding 2 matatus. And by now I had managed to beat the first one. I too had managed to finish a first freakish meetup.

On the second bus, time was flying and passengers were not boarding promptly. I grew impatient. And peeked at my wristwatch how late I was with every passing second. For moments, I wished time could stop. But then time does not wait for no man.

My nerves were on a race. Thoughts raced through my mind.

Could I possibly pull and Eliud Kipchoge? And at least cut the waiting time.

But then have never run for a long time. So, I lacked the stamina and breath to pull the run.
In the nervy moments of wait, I appointed myself the makanga. I would glance painfully at the empty seats. And would count the extra number of passengers needed to fill the bus. Here my numeracy skills were put to test.

In my heart, I would count the empty seats and would proceed to start counting the passengers getting in.

I would go on to wish any passerby would board our bus. Unfortunately, not all would get in as if they had earlier chatted with Miguna. And inspired by ‘am not boarding’ wave.

Amidst all this confusion and nervousness one my soul was kept at peace: ‘if the role I was looking to fill was mine then it would be mine’. I comforted myself.

With being philosophical. And calling God’s name when I had played a part in getting late. Still, God forgives our transgressions when we sin.

Did the bus get full?
Eventually, passengers filled the bus. I was happy. Though late, there was hope finally I would meet my CD.

In hope, I wanted the bus to grow wings. And speed up. However, it was only wishful thinking. It couldn’t be possible. What the driver would possibly do is drive faster. Oh! My wish. But drivers are not mindreaders. So, I went by the CD to be patient for the dreaded journey.
…

Yet another wait. After the first meetup, I was needed somewhere else. Or rather I needed to attend another meetup. This meetup was also timed. Even more crucial than the first. With this one, I had no luxury of time-wasting. Had to be spot on.

Did I tell you how the first meetup went? It went well.

I learnt a lot. First and very important: you can do anything in your life. It’s not too late. It’s only late when you’re dead. And even at the point of eternal rest, you’re doing something different. Offering value to the mites in the underworld.

The second lesson that supports the first is to be a student of human nature. Human nature guides most of our interactions. And can help you fit your ambitions into the world.

To culminate the learning session I learnt if all does not go well and according to your plan BE ADAPTABLE.

I finished the meetup with a see you around. Weirdly enough, I have never come around to know the best way to end up a meetup. In hesitation, most times I do the ‘see you around and thank you for your time’.

The meetup ended and I look forward to working with the CD in future as he awaits my response of sending him my CV for his evaluation.

Where was I in my wait for passengers to fill the bus?

I am in a rich suburb. Seemingly everyone here owns a vehicle. So by the mercies of the Lord will this bus get filled? I thought to myself. Then in sporadic fashion passengers streamed in but not filling the bus. Few popped in and then stepped out. My faith was on balance. Seemingly the passengers not getting in won big time.

I pondered how to get to the next meetup. Thoughts crossed my mind. Should I use boda? Or a cab? I am so tense here. I eventually made a choice.

In the panic of choosing my mode of transport, time didn’t wait. As a man I am, I had to make a choice.

Cab it was. I will not disclose which cab (unless they pay: this is a hard economy. No free endorsements. Right?)

I picked up my phone. Did some touch motions on my glass. And a ride was booked. The app showed the cab was two minutes out. The two minutes elapsed. And saw car plates like the ones shown on the app. Noticing the cab I hopped on. And tyres talked to the road beneath as the driver pressed the accelerator.

On we went.

It was a small car but you could easily feel the comfort. The windows were all raised.

And on the driver’s seat sat a youthful man with a hat on. He could be my age with his ceiling being late 20s. I exchange regards with him like a Nairobian I am. He refers to the phone conversation of how I had thought he was 15 minutes away. I laugh about it.

He then asks if am rushing somewhere. To which I glean him am headed to an interview. He also shares how he has ferried a lady to an interview early morning in his moti. Beforehand he seemed a little slippery not knowing the way. Google (a former teenager) comes in handy.

On our way cruising through a mix of road-light stops, slow and fast-moving traffic I can’t help but notice the order displayed on the roads in these sides of Nairobi. There are no police officers to man the roads. Motorists seem to follow the lights by heart.

On the side, I also take note of a boda boda who is quite reckless and speeds past a stoplight. Then think to myself how they are similar everywhere else. Not observing road rules. You should care to know for the simple reason they are one of the major causes of road carnages with fatal tragedies. But then as the human that I am, also gave him the benefit of the doubt. (He could be rushing to an emergency. Maybe his daughter is sick. Or he is picking a lady in labour. There are a lot of possibilities) Meanwhile, we are all Kenyan and we’ve such traits come up to us sometimes.

Letting all those order thoughts slide we’ve managed to cover distance. On the side, my youthful driver manoeuvres past road junctions and traffic while I am taking glances of the nice neighbourhood. A serene neighbourhood with enviable urban flats.

On my clock, my heart stops racing. Why?

Will have minutes to spare for a selfie at the entrance of my destination.

We get to my destination and my driver charges me and to his surprise, I have a discount. The cab driver takes rides to make money. He’s not a charity. And for the software to give discounts, it is a huge disappointment.

I alight and walk-in grandeur like the popular Plezident Kingston. Along the way, I exchange with the security guys as their boss does. And they seem to follow through. My grandeur walk was a sigh of relief for being 127 seconds in time (if at all it matters).

I had all the majesty and kicked a** in my second meeting.

items.title: 7 Minutes With Bebeto: Stand for Apprenticeship and grow your Network in Copywriting
items.author: Bebeto Nyamwamu
items.description:
Hi Senior Copywriter & Content Marketer,

You’re senior if you’ve worked for and with Fortune 500 brands for over 5 years. In your years in service, you’ve delivered big buck returns. Making companies scramble for your services.

And you charge high to scare away the little brands, the brands that crave your services.

I guess that’s enough introduction for your striking profile.

Now there’s one thing that was thrown at me by one of you when starting out in marketing!

Need I mention him?

In one of his posts, he mentions an idea for growing skills — apprenticeship.

First, I support his thoughts on the growth of skills in the creative industry. Content marketing and copywriting are also creative niches.

Allow me to share a story in the football world.

Athlete parents sire kids. Some kids turn out to be athletes like their parents.

Why?

Because they’re apprentices of their parents. They take after the aspirations of their parents. Good thing — it starts early. So, there’s a lot of development and growth while the bones are young.

It later then turns out the kids have the talent and end up being scrambled by top clubs.

In a similar fashion, we can apprentice in copywriting and content marketing. Though it happens later in life along with career choices, you can make it worthwhile.

Personally, I’ve not passed through the University of apprenticeship. Because I’ve not been lucky enough to get someone who shares similar thoughts in spirit. Or I’ve not looked hard enough.

One thing still remains for me, I am still on to find a mentor and grow.

But then now, to the main question:

Do you agree to suggestions of apprenticeship?

This idea of apprenticeship has two-faceted benefits ( thinking rationally as a copywriter). That is ‘what is in it for me’ mentality.

The benefits are to you as a senior copywriter and the upcoming copywriter under your wings. But as a junior marketing creative, you imparting skills is the glittering benefit with less trial and error.

So, I nitro boost getting up to speed the ways of working. In so doing, you can call upon me to assist whenever you’re swamped with work or you don’t feel like working. The arrangement can be sweetened with a cut with any referral — albeit this is in my fantasy

Now to whatever arrangement you will be in, one thing will grow — your network.

Your network is your net worth — Tim Sanders

Going on further Joel Klettke says apprenticeship is a good way to learn; even though the best mentors would likely charge money and be very difficult to convince.

So, this technique is the surest way I know to guide one into being a successful marketing creative. As a true believer, you pass on hands-on skills with less distraction. Distractions from a lot of guesswork.

If you share this belief of apprenticeship, proceed to clap and comment. We’re kindred spirits. And there’s something I can learn from you as my senior. And I hope I have found in you a marketing master.

Wishes for great marketing

P.S. Could be that they’re 700 words, more or less. In either case, the number of words is only representative to provoke your thoughts.

P.P.S Get on and fight your fears.

items.title: 7 Minutes with Bebeto: You Are Doing It Wrong and that’s Why You’re Not Getting an Interview
items.author: Bebeto Nyamwamu
items.description:
Before we get started…

There is one thing that we engage in every single day — conversations with friends.

Have you ever stopped to think that in the subtlety of such affable conversions you could spark ideas?

We find out!

The beauty of the human brain

Your mind works in an unusual way…

It processes Gigabytes of information daily. Some important, some not so, yet its all data you need.

It can remember something it does not need but sweat on things you desire.

Now, it occurred to me that the conversations you make are idea mines.

With that realization I am more and more hungry for conversations. Especially those that are not small talk. (Now for you: don’t force, allow them to flow the natural way).

So, one day we start having our normal chit chat with one of my friends. It’s all random. We start from football to women. (Now if you ask my friends, am the curious one — with lots of questions)

Then out of nowhere, we get to how people miss out on job interviews.

Because he has already piqued me, I set my ears out, to make sure I don’t miss anything.

From the conversation, I learnt the valuable lesson of Resume Copywriting — formatting to arrest the recruiter’s attention

Here is the detailed tip to get your CV game on top:

What do I do to my Resume to stand out?

So, the specific tip of resume copywriting is…

Arrangement of the resume elements.

We are used to the Basic Information, Work Experience, Academic Experience, Seminars — Trainings — Awards, Skills and finally Referees format.

Today, on your fridge sticky notes in bold, write that the format is another major undoing in your CV interview.

Why?

Because the recruiter is looking for 2 things:

  1. Skills — Customized Skills.
  2. Projects.

And the 2 things are either not emphasized or they are lacking altogether.

If it were even possible, they wouldn’t need your basic information. Because your cheque needs the address.

Even more the reason most resumes end up in the dust bins. Stop thinking they are keeping them to reach out to you in the future.

Who has the space to store loads of irrelevant CVs? Worse off, they are to change. Because you will be adding in more experience.

Get your mind off what online templates have accustomed us to.

Stand out and be the next big recruitment.

Now that you know what recruiters are looking for in your CV, do you know how they should be arranged?

Format your CV in the following order:

  1. Basic Information
  2. Skills
  3. Work Experience
  4. Academic Experience
  5. Trainings — Awards — Leadership
  6. Projects
  7. Referees

Remember the basic rule of persuasion?

It’s not about you, it’s about the customer. And the customer here is the company you will work under.

So, skills come after basic information because you want to pique the recruiter — by what you will offer the company.

Secondly, projects will come before referees because you want when your recruiter is rushing to confirm your story to see how skills translate to measurable efforts.

Recruiters are in a rush to choose the best fit out of the limited time they have — considering they receive tonnes of resumes to review.

Lastly, customized skills. Be spot on with skills that match the role you are applying for. You are not a jack-of-all-trades and a master of none. Therefore, pick your strongest assets and back them up with relevant projects.

Certainly, with that, your CV will be a sore thumb.

And, I daresay, you will WIN the CV game.

Is that not what you want?

P.S. Could be that they’re 700 words, more or less. In either case, the number of words is only representative to provoke your thoughts.

P.P.S Get on and fight your fears. And read on here.
